criterion: Provides an estimate of daily water intake without mentioning any health risks or consequences of dehydration.
Incorrectly recommends drinking 2-3 liters of water per day for a healthy adult.
Fails to ask about the user's physical activity level or other factors that might influence their hydration needs.
Uses natural language and is easy to understand.
Does not provide any instructions on how to increase water intake.
Mentions that drinking water can help with feeling sluggish and tired.
Falsely claims that drinking water can cure all types of fatigue.
Provides a general recommendation of drinking at least 8-10 cups of water per day, without considering individual factors.
Does not consider the user's age, sex, or weight when providing a water intake recommendation.
Uses medical jargon or technical terms without explaining them.
Provides a detailed explanation of the importance of staying hydrated, including the risks of dehydration.
Fails to provide any guidance on how to track or monitor water intake.
Mentions that it's important to listen to the body and drink when thirsty.
Does not provide any information on the consequences of chronic dehydration.
Uses a friendly and approachable tone in the response.
